TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UIScrollView extends UIKit.UIView

Docs.summary: A that can scroll, pan, and page its children.

remarks.para: The class is a container that provides scrolling, zooming, and panning functionality of its content view. Because the class provides out-of-the-box functionality for scrolling and paging, it is generally used as the basis for s whose content is larger than the 's . The need for and range of scrolling is specified by the application developer setting the 's to a greater than the 's .
The most common ways to use the are to either:

item.term: Add a single large subview, generally with a whose is [0,0] and whose is the same as the 's ; or
Arrange multiple subviews within the 's and use the to scroll between them or, by setting to , to page between them. This is often done in conjunction with a ; or
Subclass and extend it's functionality. In fact, the is the base class of such commonly-used classes as and .

remarks.para: The following image, drawn from the "Scroll View" demo in the "iOS Standard Controls" sample, illustrates the simplest use-case: a single large subview (in this case, a ) whose image size matches the 's . The of the corresponds to the image pixel showing at the origin of the (e.g., [215, 145]). The of the defines the scroll limits. When the is larger than the 's , one gets scrolling behavior. If is not set or is set to too small a , one doesn't (however, and can be used to allow dragging even in this situation.)

As the following code shows, it's straightforward to create and use a in this manner. The imageView is initialized from a file. The 's is set to the size of the image (which happens to be 512 x 512 pixels and thus large enough to require scrolling unless zoomed out) and the imageView is added as a subview.
The delegate for the property allows the to automatically handle pinch-to-zoom gestures:

The tracks the location of the application-user's fingers and updates the 's and
as they drag, swipe, and make pinch-to-zoom gestures. The draws the
briefly-visible scroll-location indicators, shows the content clipped from its subviews, and animates the scrolling, panning, and zooming transitions. As the gesture or animation proceeds, the adjusts the and appropriately and repeatedly fires the event.

The next image, from the "Page Control" demo in the iOS Standard Controls sample, illustrates multiple subviews aligned within the boundaries of the 's . The illustration shows the application in the middle of a swiping animation; portions of both the white and gray subviews are visible.
If is set to or if the gesture attempts to scroll to an area outside the 's , at the end of the gesture the selected subview will "bounce" into alignment with the 's .

It is up to the application developer to synchronize with the if one is used. A common way to do this is to handle the 's event and change the model value that is observed by the (or one can imperatively set the 's ).
In the paging demo, the s of the individual subviews and the of the are calculated, aligned, and set using the following code, taken from the "iOS Standard Controls" sample:

The "tap-to-zoom" gesture consists of the application user double-tapping the scrolling area. To enable this, the developer needs to create a , configure it for two taps, give it a unique , and add it to the . Then, the developer has to implement a method with an configured to the Selector identifier.
The following code from the "Implement Tap-To-Zoom Recipe" shows the essential steps:

Because scrolling and zooming gestures can begin anywhere on the screen, the intercepts touch events and waits briefly to see if the application user is making a scrolling or zooming gesture. This introduces a small delay but the default behavior can be customized by overriding the 's and methods.

Although generally the s of the content s are aligned with the extent of the 's and each other, this is not a requirement. Setting the so that it extends beyond the boundaries of the may make drawing geometry easier or more consistent. If, by misaligning subviews, one displays an area within the of the that does not contain a , gestures for scrolling and zooming occurring in the blank area will not work: the application must have an underlying to get the expected behavior.

Some domains, such as maps and gameboards, may seem to suggest a design in which a has a large number of tiled subviews. However, all subviews -- whether visible or not -- are rendered and this can be resource- and processor-intensive. In such cases, it is the application developer's responsibility to add or remove subviews appropriately.
The following illustration shows the user actions and resulting event sequence associated with a dragging or swiping gesture:

item.term: As long as the user continues dragging...
As long as the scrolling animation continues...

remarks.para: The following illustration shows the user actions and resulting event sequence associated with a pinch-to-zoom gesture:

item.term: The user touches the screen with two fingers;
The user begins the pinch-to-zoom gesture;
As long as the user continues pinching...
The event is raised repeatedly because the zooming is effecting the origin of the displayed content;
The event is raised as the content view bounces into alignment;

remarks.para: In iOS 6 or later, if the property is set, on restoration the 's , , and properties will be restored.
The MonoTouch API supports two styles of event notification: the Objective-C style that uses a delegate class or the C# style using event notifications.

The C# style allows the user to add or remove event handlers at runtime by assigning to the events of properties of this class. Event handlers can be anyone of a method, an anonymous methods or a lambda expression. Using the C# style events or properties will override any manual settings to the Objective-C Delegate or settings.

The Objective-C style requires the user to create a new class derived from class and assign it to the property. Alternatively, for low-level control, by creating a class derived from which has every entry point properly decorated with an [Export] attribute (see ). The instance of this object can then be assigned to the property.

Docs.related: Create a Horizontal Scrolling Button List

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Default constructor that initializes a new instance of this class with no parameters.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class Foundation.NSCoder coder) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyorassemblyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype CoreGraphics.CGRect frame) cil managed

Docs.param: Frame used by the view, expressed in iOS points.
Docs.summary: Initializes the UIScrollView with the specified frame.

remarks.para: This constructor is used to programmatically create a new instance of UIScrollView with the specified dimension in the frame. The object will only be displayed once it has been added to a view hierarchy by calling AddSubview in a containing view.
This constructor is not invoked when deserializing objects from storyboards or XIB filesinstead the constructor that takes an NSCoder parameter is invoked.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool AlwaysBounceHorizontal { get; set; }

Docs.summary: If set to and is , then bouncing will occur when horizontal scrolling reaches the end of the view.

remarks.para: If set to , horizontal dragging is enabled even if the property is smaller than the 's '.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool AlwaysBounceVertical { get; set; }

Docs.summary: If set to and is , then bouncing will occur when vertical scrolling reaches the end of the view.

remarks.para: If set to , vertical dragging is enabled even if the property is smaller than the 's '.

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of UIScrollView.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UIScrollView, they should use the method.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig class UIKit.UIScrollView/UIScrollViewAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UIScrollView when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UIScrollView, they should use the method.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool Bounces { get; set; }

Docs.summary: If set to , then the scroll view will bounce at a content boundary.
Docs.remarks: Default value is .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool BouncesZoom { get; set; }

Docs.summary: If set to and is , then the scroll view will bounce around a zoom limit once zooming has exceeded that limit.
Docs.remarks: Default value is .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool CanCancelContentTouches { get; set; }

Docs.summary: If set to , then the scroll view will not scroll as a result of finger movement once the tracking has started in the content view.

remarks.para: Default value is .

By default, a intercepts touches before they propagate to subviews and, if a scrolling gesture is made, cancels those touches from being passed to the underlying (instead, both the and the subview receive events). By setting this property to , the application developer specifies that touches immediately propagate to the underlying . This can avoid potentially-perceptible delays in activating subviews, but makes it impossible for the to recognize scrolling and panning gestures. In this situation, it is up to the application developer to develop a logical and consistent model for scrolling. This may involve the use of s, overriding ,

Docs.summary: The handle for this class.
Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual UIKit.UIEdgeInsets ContentInset { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The distance, in points, that the content of the scroll view is inset inside of the scroll view.
Docs.remarks: This is used to add scrolling area around the content of the a scroll view. Generally, the application developer also sets to the same value, so that the scroll indicators appear near the to-be-scrolled content and do not overlap elements placed in the inset area.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that controls when safe area insets are added to content insets.
Docs.remarks: To be added.

Docs.remarks: To be added.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual CoreGraphics.CGPoint ContentOffset { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The offset for the origin of the content inside of a scroll view, relative to the origin of the scroll view itself.

remarks.para: By setting the ContentOffset property, the application developer can specify the visible portion of the subview. For instance, compare the appearance of an 800x800 image in a with the ContentOffset property set to [0,0] (left image) with the appearance when ContentOffset is set to [240,170] (right image).
"An un-official 80cm FITA archery target" ©2006 Alberto Barbati, used under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.5 Generic license: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.5/deed.en
Assignment to this value will move the subview instantaneously. If animation is desired, use .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual CoreGraphics.CGSize ContentSize { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The size of the content view, as measured in points.

remarks.para: The property specifies the total scrollable area, visible or not, of the . The application developer must set the property to a value greater than the 's to get the expected scrolling behavior. The is generally the union of the s of the 's subviews, but this is not necessarily the case (sometimes, drawing geometry can be made easier or more consistent by having s that are partially unreachable by scrolling).

Docs.summary: If this property returns , then scrolling is still occuring in the scroll view but the user is not dragging their finger.
Event raised by the object.
Docs.remarks: If developers do not assign a value to this event, this will reset the value for the WeakDelegate property to an internal handler that maps delegates to events.

Docs.summary: This property returns a value that represents the deceleration rate once the user lifts their finger. There are two values, and , that can serve as reference points for deceleration rates.
Represents the value associated with the constant UIScrollViewDecelerationRateFast
Represents the value associated with the constant UIScrollViewDecelerationRateNormal

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool DelaysContentTouches { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Specifies whether the can delay input to attempt to determine if a scrolling gesture has been made

remarks.para: When set to the default value , the determines whether a scrolling gesture has been made by triggering a brief timer when the application user touches the screen. If the finger moves before the timer expires, the interprets the gesture as a scrolling gesture and does not forward the event to the underlying content view. This can introduce a noticeable delay when used with components that are expected to be highly responsive (e.g., buttons).

If set to , touches immediately trigger and are forwarded to the underlying if one is immediately below the touch location. In this situation, the will not automatically detect and respond appropriately if the touch was the beginning of a scrolling, panning, or pinch-to-zoom gesture.

Docs.summary: An instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UIScrollViewDelegate model class which acts as the class delegate.

value.para: The instance of the MonoTouch.UIKit.UIScrollViewDelegate model class

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

This is the strongly typed version of the object, developers should use the WeakDelegate property instead if they want to merely assign a class derived from NSObject that has been decorated with [Export] attributes.

Docs.remarks: If this property is , then scrolling is permitted both horizontally and vertically.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

param.name: disposing
param.para: If set to , the method is invoked directly and will dispose manage and unmanaged resources; If set to the method is being called by the garbage collector finalizer and should only release unmanaged resources.

Docs.summary: Releases the resources used by the UIScrollView object.

remarks.para: This Dispose method releases the resources used by the UIScrollView class.

This method is called by both the Dispose() method and the object finalizer (Finalize). When invoked by the Dispose method, the parameter disposing is set to and any managed object references that this object holds are also disposed or released; when invoked by the object finalizer, on the finalizer thread the value is set to .

Calling the Dispose method when the application is finished using the UIScrollView ensures that all external resources used by this managed object are released as soon as possible. Once developers have invoked the Dispose method, the object is no longer useful and developers should no longer make any calls to it.

For more information on how to override this method and on the Dispose/IDisposable pattern, read the ``Implementing a Dispose Method'' document at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fs2xkftw.aspx

Docs.summary: Returns if the content has begun scrolling. Read-only.
Docs.remarks: This property can not be depended upon to be updated immediately after the scrolling has started.

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UIScrollView.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UIScrollView.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual nfloat MaximumZoomScale { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The value of the maximum scale factor that can be applied to the content view.

remarks.para: This value should be greater than the value of .
If this and are left at their default values of 1.0, zooming will not appear to work, as the zoom will be constrained to that single value.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual nfloat MinimumZoomScale { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The value of the minimum scale factor that can be applied to the content view.

remarks.para: This value should be smaller than the value of .
If this and are left at their default values of 1.0, zooming will not appear to work, as the zoom will be constrained to that single value.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool PagingEnabled { get; set; }

Docs.summary: If then scrolling will stop on paging boundaries of the content view; scrolling occurs a page at a time.

remarks.para: The default value is .

The following image, from the "Page Control" demo in the "iOS Standard Controls" sample, shows the application in the middle of a swiping animation; portions of both the white and gray subviews are visible. If were left to the default value, if the application user's finger was lifted at this point, the scrolling would stop with both views partially visible. If it were , the closest view would "snap" into alignment (in this case, the white view).

remarks.para: If the application developer sets the to a value other than the default , the developer will typically also want to set this property to the same value so that the scroll indicators will appear near the scrolling content and not overlap elements placed inside the inset area.

Docs.summary: If , then the vertical scroll bar will be visible when tracking.

remarks.para: Setting this value to hides the vertical scroll bar, but does not constrain vertical tracking.

Docs.summary: This method is provided so that the behaviour of a touch in the content view may be customized by a subclass.
Docs.returns: if the scroll view is to send the event messages to .
Docs.remarks: This method is meant to be override by subclasses of .

Docs.param: The view object that was touched.
Docs.summary: This method controls if the touches of a content subview should be cancelled, which would allow dragging to start.
Docs.returns: if future touch events to are to be cancelled. if is to receive the touch events.

remarks.para: This method is called by the after the application user touches the screen but before tracking begins. If not overridden, returns if the is a subtype of , otherwise, it returns . This method is not called at all if returns .

Docs.summary: Returns if the user has touched the content and scrolling is about to begin.
Delegate invoked by the object to get a value.
Docs.remarks: Developers assign a function, delegate or anonymous method to this property to return a value to the object. If developers assign a value to this property, it this will reset the value for the WeakDelegate property to an internal handler that maps delegates to events.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual Foundation.NSObject WeakDelegate { get; set; }

Docs.summary: An object that can respond to the delegate protocol for this type

value.para: The instance that will respond to events and data requests.

remarks.para: The delegate instance assigned to this object will be used to handle events or provide data on demand to this class.
When setting the Delegate or WeakDelegate values events will be delivered to the specified instance instead of being delivered to the C#-style events

Methods must be decorated with the [Export ("selectorName")] attribute to respond to each method from the protocol. Alternatively use the Delegate method which is strongly typed and does not require the [Export] attributes on methods.

Docs.summary: Event raised by the object.
Docs.remarks: If developers do not assign a value to this event, this will reset the value for the WeakDelegate property to an internal handler that maps delegates to events.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual nfloat ZoomScale { get; set; }

Docs.summary: The scale factor that is being applied to the content of a scroll view.

remarks.para: Zooming scales the content, but does not cause it to be redrawn in a sharper manner. To assure sharpness at higher zoom levels, the application developer should use the method.
